topic.title: Performance Counters

body.note: Content sourced from PMC-2141479 - Processor Complex Subsystem Engineering Document - Issue 1.17
body.p: The performance monitor (PMON) provides a highly configurable set of counters in the switch. Several types of TLPs can be monitored:

ul.li: Fully parameterizable performance counters for both the ingress and egress directions.

Provides a set of 64 fully configurable 64-bit performance event counters (indexed from 0-63). The hardware counters are actually 32-bit but firmware obfuscates this and generates 64-bit equivalent counters. All tools will show these counters are 64-bit. Each counter saturates at an all 1s value. The counter values are accessed via an indirect PCBI interface. A clear request per counter can also be issued during an indirect read request.
Each counter is configured via a set of ingress event mask registers and a set of port mask registers. When the mask bit for a particular event is set to logic 1, that counter will be updated when that event type is detected and only if the accompanying port number is enabled via the associated port mask registers . Rule Search Table(RST) hits can be enabled for accumulation via a single event mask bit. Rule configuration is done in the RST block.
Each counter can also be configured to accumulate good Posted(P)/Non-Posted(NP)/Completion(CP) TLPs in both the ingress and egress directions – that is packets that are not marked nullify or discard. Transaction Layer Packets (TLPs) are monitored at the output of the IED sub-block for ingress packets and at the output of the EED sub-block for egress packets.

A 64-bit Posted(P)/Non-Posted(NP)/Completion(CP) byte count register is also supported per port. FW aggregates data from the 32b counters and presents it as a 64b value. These counters are also accessed via an indirect PCBI interface. Each counter uses decode of the TLP packet bus interface from the IED block for ingress packets and from the EED block for egress packets. As such, packet byte count is for edited packets for both ingress and egress datapaths.
32-bits are assigned to ingress and the other 32-bits are assigned to egress
Only packets that are not marked nullify or discard are counted.

Each port also supports a set of latency status registers for egress packets (measured in ns). Egress packet latency is calculated by comparing the 32-bit timestamp for an egress packet as presented by the Egress TLP Editor (EED) block with the on-chip global. When latency for an egress packet exceeds the 16-bit granularity supported by the latency status registers, an all 1s value will be reflected for both the maximum and current status registers. The maximum latency status register is reset to an all 0s value via a self-clearing clear request bit. Note that the LSB of the timestamp is ignored by the latency registers. The latency status registers are also accessed via an indirect PCBI interface.
Each port is associated with 16-bit maximum, and current latency status registers.
Latency can be measured at each egress port through a hardware selector bit PMON_LTCY_PORT_SEL.

body.p: The Performance Counters can be controlled and configured from the Configuration File, ChipLink, and the MRPC interface. As multiple MRPC hosts and the FW CLI are all able to access PMON, there is an internal access permission mechanism to prevent conflicts. When one host or FW CLI is accessing PMON, other hosts or FW CLI cannot access PMON until the host or FW CLI releases the access permission. The access permission acquisition and release is automatic. If access to PMON is refused, the access attempt can simply be retried after a delay.

fig.title: PMON Block Diagram and Implementation Details

ol.li:
Dump counter status
pmon -dmpall <-all|-bw|-ev|-ltcy> <rdClr(0:No|1:Yes)>
<-all|-bw|-ev|-ltcy> indicates what kind(s) of counters status to dump.
<rdClr> indicates whether clear the counters after reading or not. “0” means not clear and “1” means clear after reading.

Configurate event counter
pmon -evcnt -cfg <stk#> <prtMsk> <tyMsk> <cntIdx(0-63)> <IEg(0:ingress|1:egress)> <threshold>
<stk#)> indicates the stack number.
<prtMsk> indicates which port(s) to monitor by this event counter. Bit 0 indicates port 0 of this stack. Bit 1 indicates port 1… Set each bit to logic 1 to enable the corresponding port.
<tyMsk> is to select counter event. 23 events are supported now.
<cntIdx> indicates which event counter to configure.
<IEg> indicates ingress or egress TLP to count. “0” means ingress and “1” means egress. This parameter is only valid for “POSTED_TLP_CNT”, “COMPLETION_TLP_CNT” and “NONPOSTED_TLP_CNT” events. Other events are only working on ingress TLPs.
<threshold> When the counter reached threshold value, a per port event would be notified.

Dump event counter status
pmon -evcnt -sts <stk#> <cntIdx(0-63)> <rdClr(0:No|1:Yes)>
<stk#> indicates the stack where the event counter is.
<cntIdx> indicates which event counter to dump status.
<rdClr> indicates whether clear the counter after reading. “0” means not clear while “1” means clear the counter after reading.

Configurate latency counter
pmon -ltcy -cfg <prt#> <srcPrtSel(63:all source ports|0-55:single source port)>
<prt#> is the physical port ID of latency counter.
<srcPrtSel> TLP from which port(s) to monitor the latency. “63” indicates all of the ingress port in this device. “0-55” indicates a dedicated ingress port to monitor. “56-62” are invalid input that latency would not be monitored.

Dump latency counter status
pmon -ltcy -sts <prt#> <rdClr(0:No|1:Yes))>
<prt#> is the physical port ID of latency counter.
<rdClr> indicates whether clear the counter after reading. “0” means not clear while “1” means clear the counter after reading.

Select/deselect RST rule for error hole in memory space expected no transaction
pmon -rst -err <stk[0-5]> <part> <0:T|1:NT> <0:addrRouting|1:IDRouting> <MMIO[0:IO|1:Prefetch|2:Non-prefetch]> <0:deselect|1:select> <cntIdx(0-63)>
<stk#> indicates the stack number.
<part> indicates the partition number the rule is working for.
<0:T|1:NT> indicates the rule for error TLP routing is of Transparent mode or Non-transparent mode. “0” means Transparent mode while “1” means Non-transparent mode.
<0:addrRouting|1:IDRouting> indicates which type of error TLP routing rule to select/deselect for event counting. “0” means address routing TLP. That means IO and MWR/RD TLP.“1” means ID routing TLP. That means Completion TLP. Please note Transparent mode and Non-transparent mode share the same rule for error ID routing TLPs.
<MMIO[0:IO|1:Prefetch|2:Non-prefetch]> indicates MMIO type of the address routing error TLP routing rule to select/deselect for event counting. “0” indicates IO address range. “1” indicates Prefetchable address range. “2” indicates non-prefetchable address range. This parameter is only valid for address routing type.
<0:deselect|1:select> indicates this command is to select this rule for match counting to deselect.
<cntIdx(0-63)> indicates which event counter to add by 1 when this rule match happened.

Select/deselect RST rule for implicit TLP
pmon -rst -im <stk[0-5]> <part> <0:Cfg|1:Message> <0:deselect|1:select> <cntIdx(0-63)>
<stk#> indicates the stack number.
<part> indicates the partition number the rule is working for.
<0:Cfg|1:Message> indicates routing rule for which type of TLP to select/deselect for event counting. “0” means all configuration TLP. “1” means all message TLP.
<0:deselect|1:select> indicates this command is to select this rule for match counting to deselect.
<cntIdx(0-63)> indicates which event counter to add by 1 when this rule match happened.

Select/deselect RST rule for TLP to USP with different routing type
pmon -rst -usp <stk[0-5]> <part> <0:addrRouting|1:IDRouting> <0:deselect|1:select> <cntIdx(0-63)>
<stk#> indicates the stack number.
<part> indicates the partition number the rule is working for.
<0:addrRouting|1:IDRouting> indicates which type of error TLP routing rule to select/deselect for event counting. “0” means address routing TLP. That means IO and MWR/RD TLP.“1” means ID routing TLP. That means Completion TLP. Please note Transparent mode and Non-transparent mode share the same rule for error ID routing TLPs.
<0:deselect|1:select> indicates this command is to select this rule for match counting to deselect.
<cntIdx(0-63)> indicates which event counter to add by 1 when this rule match happened.

Select/deselect RST rule for TLP to DSP with different routing type
pmon -rst -dsp <stk[0-5]> <part> <dsp_logical_port[1-47]> <0:addrRouting|1:IDRouting> <MMIO[0:IO|1:Prefetch|2:Non-prefetch]> <0:deselect|1:select> <cntIdx(0-63)>
<stk#> indicates the stack number.
<part> indicates the partition number the rule is working for.
<dsp_logical_port[1-47]> is the logical DSP ID of this partition. The range is from 1 to 47. Here “0” indicates USP.
<0:addrRouting|1:IDRouting> indicates which type of error TLP routing rule to select/deselect for event counting. “0” means address routing TLP. That means IO and MWR/RD TLP.“1” means ID routing TLP. That means Completion TLP. Please note Transparent mode and Non-transparent mode share the same rule for error ID routing TLPs.
<MMIO[0:IO|1:Prefetch|2:Non-prefetch]> indicates MMIO type of the address routing error TLP routing rule to select/deselect for event counting. “0” indicates IO address range. “1” indicates Prefetchable address range. “2” indicates non-prefetchable address range. This parameter is only valid for address routing type.
<0:deselect|1:select> indicates this command is to select this rule for match counting to deselect.
<cntIdx(0-63)> indicates which event counter to add by 1 when this rule match happened.

topic.title: Counter Types and Event Triggers

body.p: The performance monitor provides 3 types of counters: bandwidth counters, latency counters, and event counters.

Bandwidth counters provide per-port byte counts (expressed in raw bytes with TLP header) for Posted, Non-posted and Completion type TLPs for both ingress and egress directions. The time interval of these TLPs going through the port is also recorded, allowing calculation of the bandwidth on a per-port basis. The TLP byte counters are 32-bit counters that are accumulated by FW to 64-bit counters.

Each port also supports a latency counter for egress packets. The latency counter provides a 16bit maximum latency counter field and a 16bit current counter field. The maximum latency counter records maximum latency of TLPs from a configurable source ingress port to this egress port since the last time the counter was cleared. The current latency counter indicates the latency of the most recent TLP that passed through this egress port. The user has capability to choose one ingress port or all of the ingress ports of the device to monitor TLP latency.

There are 64 event counters in each stack. Each counter indexed from 0-63 is configured via ingress event mask parameter and port mask parameter. When the mask bit for a particular event is set, that counter will be updated when that event type is detected and only if the accompanying port number is enabled via the associated port mask parameter. The supported events are: AER errors, routing rule match events and NAK indications from DLL/PL. Each counter can also be configured to accumulate good P/NP/CP TLPs in both the ingress and egress directions – that is packets that are not marked nullify or discard. Please note ingress and egress direction selection is only supported for P/NP/CP TLP accumulation. Other event monitors only work for ingress TLPs.
